line.commentary: This opening line sets up a profound comparison using 孰 (which/who), asking us to weigh two important concepts. Notice how 與 (and/with) is setting up comparisons throughout the first several lines.
Notice how this line follows the exact same grammatical pattern as the first - this parallel structure is a key feature of Classical Chinese poetry.
The third parallel question introduces 得 (gain) and 亡 (lose) - consider how these concepts might relate to the previous lines about possessions and self.
Notice how 必 (must) creates a cause-and-effect relationship between the two parts of this statement.
Here's a powerful contrast - 知 (know) paired with 足 (enough). How might this relate to the previous lines about gain and loss?
This concluding line uses 可以 (can/able) to introduce a result. Consider how this ties together all the previous concepts about knowing limits and avoiding excess.
